mil5.5.9:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil5.5.9:1.1_0: “When the Buddha spoke like this, he said,
mil5.5.9:10.2_0: A monk approaches families and stays mindfully. He stands on the spots without conditions, and goes to the thirteen, tied to the moment, and sets out taking leave.
mil5.5.9:10.3_0: But this person is known as suffering, and they enjoy themselves. Even when they don’t examine the noble ones, they’re considered a categoricality of the body, and they’re considered to be known as pure.

mil5.5.9:11.3_0: Though a noble disciple has nothing left over,

mil5.5.9:12.2_0: It’s when a mendicant asks for many kinds of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. But they don’t remember.

mil5.5.9:16.2_0: It’s when a mendicant keeps their medicine from family to family that is likable, desirable, and agreeable, but they think of the noble ones.
mil5.5.9:17.1_0: And when a Realized One does not receive food, he’s able to give up that boiled rice. The Realized One does not take up that almsfood.”
